review: In Canada, this device works primarily to play Netflix and Youtube.  It does it well, controlled by either my iPod or my computer.  As an added bonus, I can "cast" webpages I'm looking at to the screen.  It can do more in the US ... but I was simply looking for something inexpensive that plays Netflix with better picture image than my Wii and it does it well for the price.

review: The Google Chromecast Player is an easy to install, easy to use device for watching HD video, whether your own or streamed from commercial sources.  The only deficit is the small number of commercial video suppliers.  It would be great to add the Amazon live streaming and Vimeo.  Then I would give it 5 stars.
author: Bob Liles

review: This thing is cool. It converts "dumb" or "quasi smart" tvs into a more intuitive user experience.  If you want to stream movies, shows, etc, this is the best add on hardware for the job.  Also, seems like there is a lot of room for updates/upgrades in the future, so I'm sure it will only get cooler.  For $25-$35 dollars, it's a no brainer.One thing to note, this thing needs more power than the HDMI can supply, so you have to plug it into a USB port on your TV (adapter included) or you have to buy another adapter that plugs into the wall (or you can use one of your old cell phone USB adapters).  This worth noting because if you're like me you probably assumed this thing simply plugged into a free HDMI port and you would be good to go...not true.  Most new TVs have a USB, so this shouldn't be a problem, but if yours does not be prepared to plug it into the wall.

review: Very disappointed.  I expected better from Google.The setup failed several times before I was able to get it to work.  But then it got worse.  Everything I cast would be out of sync.  Sound and picture doesn't come close.  Tried online support and performed all of the recommended actions, but still no love.  About the only thing that comes close to syncing is Hulu Plus.  The rest is just not usable.This definitely doesn't feel like a commercially ready product.  Save yourself time and get a Roku.
